name: Woodall's conjecture
rephrased: For any directed graph, the size of the smallest set of edges (called a 'dijoins') that covers all directed edges is equal to the size of the largest set of edges (called a 'dicut') that separates the graph into two parts with all edges going in one direction.
implication_form: If a directed graph has a dicut of size k, then it has a dijoin of size k.
explained: Woodall's conjecture states that if a directed graph has a dicut of size k (i.e., a partition of the vertex set into two parts A and B such that all arcs from A to B are present and there are k such arcs), then there exists a dijoing (a set of k arcs that form an arborescence rooted at some vertex) of size at most k.
